newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's Sega and Bandai to merge into toy giant.
newsitem.headline: Japan's Sega and Bandai to merge into toy giant.

text.p: Japanese video-game giant Sega Enterprises Ltd and toy-maker Bandai Co. Ltd, said Thursday they would merge in October, creating what they called "a formidable force" in the media entertainment business.
Rival Sony Corp. expressed surprise and behemoth Nintendo Co. Ltd shrugged off the move with a "no worries" comment.

Analysts said the merger of Sega, maker of the Sega Saturn 32-bit video-game player, and Bandai, known for its Dragon Ball, Power Ranger and Sailor Moon character toys, posed little threat to Sony's growing grip on the game player market.
But the corporate marriage could give Sega-Bandai, as the new firm will be known, a head start in the race to profit by linking televisions, video games and the Internet, some analysts said.
Sega and Bandai said the merged firm would benefit from Sega's video game, virtual reality and computer graphics technologies and from Bandai's know-how in charactor toys, images and music.

"We would like to become a global, comprehensive, new entertainment company and expand further internationally," Sega President Hayao Nakayama said in announcing the merger, noting the new firm would have annual sales of 600 billion yen ($5.04 billion).
Under the terms of the deal, Bandai shareholders will receive 0.76 Sega share for each share of Bandai they hold, representing a modest 8 percent premium over the market value.

That small reward is due in part to a sharp rise in Bandai shares and a moderate fall in Sega's stock before the deal was announced. Based on the prices the day before, the deal would have offered Bandai shareholders a 20 percent premium.
Sega has been suffering from competition with Sony's popular 32-bit PlayStation as well as the 64-bit Nintendo 64.
"This merger probably expresses the feeling of crisis at Sony's growing video-game market dominance," one analyst said.
Analysts say Sony's PlayStation has been pulling ahead by winning over some key software houses.
"I don't think the (new) firm can beat Sony's PlayStation in any way," said Yasuo Imanaka, an analyst at Okasan Economic Research Institute.

Last December, Sega -- plagued by excess inventory of 16-bit games and by losses at its U.S. unit -- slashed its forecast for group net profits in the year to March 1997 almost in half, to 5.3 billion yen ($44.5 million).
Bandai also has its own troubles.
Earlier this month, the toymaker forecast a net loss of 9 billion yen ($75.6 million) instead of the 10.50 billion yen ($88.2 million) profit seen earlier.
In November, Bandai admitted misreading market trends by sticking to expensive character toys while the popularity of less costly items like 500-yen ($4) mini-cars soared.
"It is hard to see a merit in the merger," said Imanaka said. "Both companies have problems in similar fields."
Still, the future might hold more promise.

Struggling Apple Computer Inc. is betting that a "Pippin" Internet appliance launched with Bandai will spell success in a "third computing age" of multi-media systems and the Internet. Pippin, a small black box that sits on top of a TV set, is as easy to connect as a video cassette recorder. It uses an unobtrusive keyboard or video game controller for input.
Apple has said it believes Pippin, at a suggested retail price of $599, would become the information access method of choice for families who cannot afford or do not want a computer.
"The merger will provide Sega certain competitiveness in next-generation game machines," said Masahiro Ono, an analyst at Credit Lyonnaise Securities.
